job_title: Marketing Director in New York, NY
pros: Work/iife balance is really true before the VP level.  The company is dominated by women, who are often the lower-earning part of a dual-income family.  The time off is ample and employees can't roll over their days, which indicates that senior leadership supports time off.  The people and culture are refined, meaning that people treat each other fairly well in meetings and during presentations.  Most of the people are very smart, creative more on the beta-side meaning an emphasis on collaboration vs alpha side meaning goal or results oriented.  The focus on customers and customer satisfaction is genuine which senior leaders actually reading letters from customers and sending them to to you if it effects your area.
cons: The matrix-culture waters down a lot of good, original ideas because so many people can shape/influence the outcome.  This also means it takes an incredibly long time to make the simplest decision since everyone and their brother needs to hear about it.  This means a lot of presentations and follow ups before you can even implement.  This also effects promotions and meritocracy, so getting ratings is essentially a popularity contest.  If everyone likes you and you've done a decent job, then you'll get a good rating. However, if someone is annoyed they can tank your rating through the annual alignment process.  Plus the technology group is terrible on the interactive side.  What else explains a 4 second load time on the home page and below-market recurring billing???

pros:
The number one pro is the people you will work with: Amex attracts people who are not only smart and driven to succeed, but in general are willing to help others along the way. It is a highly collaborative environment - in part this is forced by the matrixed organizational structure, and this can be a negative in that it slows down decision-making, but it is also an outcome of the type of individuals who get hired, and who stick around.
Second, while it is a brand-driven company renowned for its advertising, it is a fundamentally sound business with extraordinary attention paid to risk assessment and quantifiable outcomes. If you don't have a finance background or an aptitude for numbers you can certainly get by, but if you can combine quant savvy with creative thinking and influencing skills you will do very well.
Management is generally very open to work-life balance needs, and takes employee development and satisfaction extremely seriously. There are exceptions of course, but there are a lot of good people leaders here.
cons: Performance doesn't always guarantee career success - beyond a certain level - probably Director or above - you need a senior leader acting as your 'champion', to get you in the door and then keep you moving forward. The company tends to dip its toes in cutting edge segments, but when times get tough they are the first to go regardless of their strategic, long-term importance. The need to manage multiple stakeholders for every decision can be frustrating, and often there is no clear 'owner' for a decision.

Amex goes on a 12-18 month cycle of layoffs, and they seem to be getting deeper and more frequent.  People don't often quit the company, but the constant spectre of layoffs feels like a game of Russian roulette sometimes.  

Because the company is so mature, they have very rigid processes.  They're trying to establish an entrepreneurial splinter group to develop mobile applications to stay competitive, and they've deliberately kept it separate from the rest of Technologies so it can function more like a west coast start-up company. I was unfortunate to have a toxic manager & director which made me miserable during my 2 years at Amex. My team mates felt the same way and left for the same reason. The team that replaced us is now also feeling the same way and planning to leave too (so I know I wasn't an isolated case).

If I wasn't so unfortunate, I would have loved to stay longer.

Although I would still recommend working at Amex to friends, I will highly discourage anyone from joining my ex-team.

review_title: Experience can vary depending on department
job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good benefits, you can find jobs with a good work-life balance, fairly easy for most people to change jobs every few years so it doesn't get monotonous. I like the culture for the most part, some great managers and some mediocre ones. A lot of ambitious and smart employees to work with.
cons: Stack ranking system is awful...someone HAS to get the low rating, and very few can get the best rating. Creates a sense of competition rather than cooperation. In one department I worked in, job descriptions often changed frequently and you were expected to have skills different from the ones you were hired for, which was frustrating. Reorganization is very frequent. Can be hard to advance if you're not lucky...they keep sending jobs offshore rather than filling them here. Any tech project you work on, you have to work with folks in India and the time difference and communication barrier can make it challenging. In some departments, you are constantly fighting fires because they don't have the budget to be more proactive.

pros: American Express offers a wide variety of payment products for the consumer and business community.  The overall direction of the company is good and the opportunity for success does exist. I enjoyed most of my 14 years and would recommend the opportunity to most people - if you are looking for a Sales position and know about payment products.
cons: The executive's are highly regarded in the industry and are really great at taking the company in a positive direction; however, they are very isolated and keep themselves in the ivory tower.  Middle  Management in many areas lacks the ability to lead and effectively manage the large number of employees they are responsible for.  There is no clear career path for longer term employees and no real sense of company commitment for loyalty.

job_title: Director in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: American Express promotes an incredible work / life balance.  Some areas have flexible work arrangements, allowing you to work from home.  Their vacation time is extremely generous, and corporate culture is incredible.  The company is a leader in diversity, and everyone is respected.  Promotions are possible, and the company highly regards promoting from within.
cons: With the loss of Costco, the company has downsized A LOT.  The CEO reaction to poor leadership decisions, or a dip in the share price, is to lay people off.  While the corporate culture is phenomenal, the company hasn't kept pace with younger consumers, and is losing market share.  High performers are leaving in droves and finding places to work, that are more profitable.  It's no longer the company that it used to be.

review_title: Trying to be the Google of the FINTECH world
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Work-Life balance,  benefits are on par with the banking/financial industry,  but salaries are hit or miss.  If you sell yourself short coming into the company it's going to be difficult to obtain industry norms.
cons:
They've gone from a relatively cautious, adverse organization to pretend like they're some bleeding edge Silicon Valley powerhouse.   Some fresh out of college "consultant" recommendations rewriting the core authorization platform (currently written in Assembly language) in Go and leadership takes it under serious consideration.  LOL!!!  Really? 

Again, they're trying to be something they're not and that spells disaster for the "workers" that have to "tow the line" to meet unrealistic demands while dealing with constant reorgs and cost cutting initiatives.  It used to be that Lead Programmer Analysts should be SMEs and team leaders that didn't code much at all.  Now, even the VPs are expected to be able to write code and pass coding exams if applying  from outside of the company  and that is just a tad ridiculous.  

One thing holds true;  AMEX is a GREAT place to work.....IF you end up in the right group.

pros: Great benefits. Great pay. Exceptional facilities in the office. Opportunity to grow within the company. Most of management are friendly.
cons:
The past couple years they have become extremely sales driven to the point of being unproductive. They push you to sell card products and if you don't meet their completely unreasonable sales requirement they will write you up for it.
Incentive is mostly based on customer surveys. If you receive a bad survey you could lose a portion/all of your incentive that you worked hard for. Even if you received the survey by error and it clearly wasn't intended for you, they won't do anything about it and you will lose and incentive because of their error.
They penalize you for taking a bathroom break even if you have a medical condition and provide them with a doctors note. 
Endless fighting with other departments within the company because of lazy reps who don't want to be handling a call they should be handling.

review_title: Lacks governance and structure and is too US centric...
pros: The people are great, some of the nicest I've worked with.  It is a very inclusive culture and truly does value diversity.  The leadership development and training used to be good, but I've seen a very distinct decline since 2008.  The working environment tends to be relaxed and informal
cons: It is too US centric with very little understanding from the US of cultural differences in the approach to work in the other regions.  There is a lack of discipline, structure and governance around process and working methodology (though efforts are being made to improve, but this should really have been done at the front end - not as an after thought). Organisationally, it is very hierarchical and career progression is relationship based rather than merit.  There is a certain level of hypocrisy and a distinct difference between what is said by leadership and what is actually done.  As it's a US company, there's a bit too much 'ra ra' and company flag waving for my liking....

review_title: The combined RLA/Dart (Responsible Lending Action Team and Dart (Deceased Account Resolution Team) Call Center
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Team Members are friendly and will assist you with questions and will always help you.
cons: Stressful, unrealistic expectations by management, low pay, and low paying incentives.  In the RLA  segment under the Account Services (Credit) Department we are expected to deliver negative information to card members such as why we lowered their credit limit or cancelled their Amex account but do it in a way so that we may get a possitive T-Bass (Employee Survey e-mailed to the card members we interacted with).  This segment  (RLA/Dart) pays the least in incentives.  The way raises work (raises are rated 1, 2 or 3 with "1" being the best.  is that the Company will only allow a certain small percentage to get a "1," and then there is another percentage that will be rated as "2." Finally there is the percentage that will be rated as "3."  So, if there are a number of employees in a segment who are all about equal,  the team leaders get together and plead their case as to who should be rated as "1,"

review_title: Great company, but its a toss up as to the quality of training and your manager.
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great benefits and a lot of resources on-site like cafeteria, nurse practitioner, etc. Everyone is nice and easy to get along with.
cons: While nice, some manager styles are not ideal resulting in training that isn't successful. Contradicting or completely false information from different coaches and an inability to fight to keep employees they say have great promise but aren't meeting goals because of a lack of support or accurate information. They have a style of training that may be improving, but up to now has not been successful since only 60% of one specific class actually gets out of training and stays with the company.

review_title: Glorified team leads called engineering directors
pros:
People in engineering teams are great to work with.
Great initial days.
Newly formed teams are great. Not so much the same for teams with directors who are in the company for more than 10 years . They do not connect with people well.
cons:
Well .. where do i start ?
Politics is clearly visible in every decision taken including how parking spaces are allocated.  As for progressions , If you are a woman -  make sure you dress and make-up well to be recognised by inexperienced engineering directors(well they do not do engineering btw,they are team leaders conducting 1-1s) and in recent years 1-1 has been the most important meeting for anyone in Burgess Hill. Gentlemen - be prepared for your skills and experience and creative ideas to be overlooked if you are thinking skills,expertise and experience are criteria for progression .  Glorified leaders are looking for something additional which will not be your core skill that you are in the company for. Dont blame the directors though, it is few engineers who encourage them by giving importance which is unnecessary.
Which organizations allocates double parking spaces for leadership and denies a single parking space to other employees at lower bands ?
Team meetings are nothing but joke. And again they are really high up in appraisal criteria.

review_title: It was fun, but you will feel cornered
pros: The company has is very good at hiring people (customer care professionals). You will find great friends in this organisation. Additionally, the infrastructure in place is good, as well as little benefits like health care, free food is common. Management in general will treat you well.
cons: The biggest downside is that if you do TOO WELL as a Customer Care Professional, you will not be promoted to other roles in the organisation. Your metrics are your leader's metrics as well and as such they do not have any incentive to lead you to other roles - its sad. Its very common to see people with not so great results get promoted, because their manager does not want them. However this is isolated to the Customer Care Professional role and teams only. Other teams I have been in are normal (I didn't have the best statistics and I was promoted).

pros: Although the benefits don't compare to what they were 30 years ago, they are still better than most businesses out there. With Technology always changing Amex keeps up the pace and is always looking for improvements. The changes keep you constantly learning and keeps it interesting.
cons: Benefits are not as good as they were 30 years ago. Too many technology changes being implemented too fast to where they are not always complete and create issue for the end users.

job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Let's you move around to different roles
cons: Culture does not support diversity

review_title: Overall a good company to work for; benefits are the best in the business!
pros: American Express is a very structured company with friendly management and diverse practices. They are very open to giving and receiving feedback which I think is essential to job success.The company is very open to assisting with the work/life balance and has many benefits including a considerable amount of free benefits that assist with family life and a heathly living way of life.
cons: The management is often too young and inexperienced and are not always the best at being impartial to all employees regardless of if they are the same age or spend time together outside of work. They are also often distracted with the latest sports event or television shows as opposed to leading by example in a business environment as a professional.

review_title: It's a mix of both positive and negative attributes
pros:
Excellent training especially on the phone
Rich incentives(as long as you meet/exceeds the metrics)
Always something going on(so many committee you can join in)
Excellent work development and support(concrete action plan)
Very positive coach(mine was, she was the best in my entire career)
Diverse workforce/culture(like World University)

Phoney people(esp those that are band 30- they think their higher than Ken Chenault)

Big brother house(keeping track of your time/got to write my time even going to bathroom, so I can make it up)

review_title: Takes Risk Investment Vision & Guts to steer a 150+ year old behemoth. We do it every day.
pros:
Values based company - treat each other with respect & dignity. 
Flex Time
Paid Time Off Accrual
100% Vesting, company match up to 5% in 401K 
Benefits from Day One
Good Leadership Opportunities
Global Company with Interest in Cutting Edge Digital Direction
Hires Well most of the time. Slow to fire.
cons:
Poor Interview Process 
Reliability on Networking 
Most of the time leader is not going to be your advocate due to current climate / downsizing.
Outsource critical functions for shareholder benefit at risk of long time loyal people. 
Slow in some departments to invest fast enough or support dead end projects where other more viable forward thinking solutions are readily available out of the box. 
To many layers of management. 
Very top heavy in pay distribution above people leader/contributor levels.

review_title: Not Bad, But Better Out There
pros: The call centre departments are very supportive in providing a good environment for employee development.  The benefits are comprehensive.  It was a good corporate culture prior to the restructuring.
cons: Restructuring has changed the company significantly.  They pay much less than the industry average yet their HR department claims that wages are up to industry standard.  They don't hold senior management accountable for their behaviour, especially the Technology department.  It's run like an old boys club and only those that play the game and kiss the buts get promoted.  And then sadly, mis-manage then get demoted - shouldn't have been promoted in the first place.  Certain favoured individuals  and teams get registered secretly for company paid training but others are not approved for it and lame excuses made up.  2+ Technology VP's abruptly jumped ship - I wonder why.

review_title: Strong Talent, bureaucracy abounds - if you can navigate this place is for you!
pros: The diverse set of talent across the organization, helps to keep you exposed to new ideas and forces you to understand your own career inspirations/direction as many folks just know what they want to do when they 'grow up'. Pay is reasonable and if you are in marketing this is a premier brand to take with you anywhere.
cons: In a word, bureaucracy. Amex is the premier expert in creating silos and tearing down ease of work in order to increase the complexity of doing business. Many times the ideas are sound and might even make sense, until you've been around a while and its clear that politics are usually the biggest drivers for centralizing or decentralizing (and back again) a specific organization. The fact that we are in a very challenging time almost allows this type of behavior to go on, the best power players will survive, those with less skill will be posting on LinkedIn...

review_title: Don't Stay at Amex Too Long
job_title: Director Marketing in New York, NY
pros:
Outstanding company with brand that I am proud of and use myself.
Easy to explain where I work and what I do
Good work life balance but be careful...
cons:
Even though their best customers are over 45 years old,  Amex is very focused on youth when it comes to it's employees.  
Amex does not value real experience in it's work force.  It' nearly impossible to find a upper middle manager (AKA Band 45 VP) that became a VP after age 35.  Most experienced employees are pushed aside after a certain age regardless of how successful and award winning they have been to make room for the next generation.
So don't stay too long.  If you miss more than two opportunities to get promoted it's time to leave.

review_title: They are a fair company that respects the value of work life balance
pros:
Mat Leave and Pat leave programs are very good...
blue works is a great program for those with 60+ min commutes
Tons of lateral movements available
Its like an extension of college - you will continue to learn and gain skill sets as your career progresses
American express is an incredible brand to be associated with and you will get to focus on the customer and have a tangible effect on the customer.
cons:
depending on who your leader is, that work life balance culture that Amex preaches by can be affected...
compensation is barely keeping up with the cost of living, especially in NY...
Political game play is always an issue...
its very difficult to grow and follow a career path if you are focused on a particular part of the business. To be successful you must be willing to take any job in the company at any point regardless of your interest.

pros: Good vibe within the company, on the leading edge of technology innovation.  The company as a whole has great values and is good to their employees.
cons: Senior Leadership In technology organization is bloated with good old boys.  They play the diversity card and gender equality but reality is, the new CIO doesn't practice what he preaches.  The company will continue to lay off good employees due to the senior level bloating.  It was a shame that Ed Gilligan pass unexpectedly this year, he was an amazing leader and would have taken Amex into the future.  The current leadership cannot get out of the past.

pros:
Good work/life balance
Decent pay given relatively low stress level
Not a bad name on the resume
Smart colleagues although they are all leaving
cons: Highly political. All organizations are political to some extent especially at the top, but in recent years, politics at Amex are felt day to day even at the lowest level. Capable people are leaving one after another because of poor leadership. Reorgs were claimed to help reduce layers but somehow there's even more vps and directors bs-ing around post-integration. From ceo down to half of the managers,  no one actually knows what the strategy really is. They think leadership means nothing but shouting out buzzwords as if repeating "we need to grow" can magically result in actual growth. Lots of people just want to "project manage", and feel entitled that someone else should do the actual work. In reality,  the organization as a whole simply don't have real skills.

review_title: Good company overall, but if you end up in a bad team........
pros: Competitive pay, good benefits, company trying to reinvent itself as a technology company and trying to move at a rapid pace, meaning a lot of opportunities to learn and work on modern tools. If you are lucky then you might end up working on really cool products as well. Senior leadership is pushing everyone in the organization to get technical.
cons: Struggling to shake of the vendor dominated technology teams, a lot of leaders from back in time have no clue of running teams. Historically they had all vendors (very substandard folks and too much control) so some leaders rely heavily on vendors and have no idea of how to hire, mentor full time employees. Too much politics if you end up in really toxic teams (trust me there are plenty), a lot of attrition in such teams doesn't help with the morale.

job_title: Director, Business Development in New York, NY
pros:
1) work life balance
2) In the right BU, broad responsibility
3) Young, highly intelligent colleagues - best bschools
4) Great place to learn about the power of brand and customer service
5) Job rotation culture
6) Great resume brand
cons:

2) Passive aggressive culture - slows decision-making

review_title: American Express Used To Be A Good Company To Work For
pros: Liberal paid time off and good benefits.
cons: American Express used to hire travel counselors for their travel expertise and customer service skills, but they refuse to pay for those skills.  In addition, the focus is now to take as many calls per hour as possible.  The concept of 'wowing the customer' is something management touts and talks about, but refuses to provide the time necessary to do that.  It's funny...American Express expects employees to tell Cardmembers what they can/will do for them, but the company refuses to do that for their employees in return.  This has led to low morale and high turnover, with new hires not being qualified to replace departed employees.

review_title: AMEX so much potential and yet so little real results
pros:
The work life balance - at least in our organization - is outstanding. They honor my need to support my children in their school and athletic functions. 

The planning and overall project governance is lacking and seems to be knee jerk - when it comes to implementing new processes and methods. Most are attempted while still expecting outstanding project results.

Relationships are big at AXP. The encourage work with groups outside our organization and provide access to training and certification resources as needed. Most of the people are technically proficient and don't hesitate to share valuable information or support your project needs upon request.
cons:
Good ole' boy network alive and well, especially with some of the organizations run by non-US leaders. 

Planning is not intelligently carried out. It is not really executed until January and then projects don't get fully up and running until February or March - and then the network freeze at the end of the year make November and December very unproductive as well.

review_title: A great company, excellent culture and amazing benefits  - Ive worked for American Express for 13 years.
pros: Very structured company.  Promote from within the company which allows employee growth.   Salary  is on par with market rate and rather fair compared to what is offered out in the workplace. Benefits are awesome.
cons: Work life balance is a Zero. There is no job security at American Express. Today you are here and promised a wonderful future and suddenly the next day you are left without a job and a nice thank you, but Im sorry statement.   The US Call Centre has just closed its doors and hundreds of faithful employees lost their jobs one bright Tuesday morning last year June.  The center will close its doors shortly and taking jobs back to the USA -
